w:r.w:t: TITLE: Rural, Suburban and Urban Communities

The teacher will teach three main communities by using TPR, sentence frames, and vocabulary. Students will study these words and phrases: communities, where do you live, What do you see/hear in a suburban/rural/urban community, I see/hear ____, traffic, less, fewer, houses, buildings, barns, animals, rural, suburban, urban
At completion of this lesson, students will be able to:
Recognize, spell, and pronounce the words for kinds of communities
Spell and pronounce common associated words
Use sets of words in complete sentences
Word List: communities, rural, urban, suburban
This slide will always be the Naativ-branded opener slide that the teacher will display as the student enters the classroom.
Greet your student and introduce the lesson concept: “Today, we are going to be learning about the kinds of communities!”

Do you live in a house, Do you live on a farm, Do you live in an apartment, etc.

Read the slide to the child and simply explain that there are three kinds of places we live. Ask they child if they live by animals (and circle the barn), if they live by a lot of buildings (and circle the tall buildings) or if they live in a house (circle the house). Tell the child to circle the kind of community they live in.

Have the child repeat. Explain that traffic is ALL kinds of cars, trucks, buses, motorcycles, etc. Ask the child what kinds of traffic they see. Prompt them to circle the cars, circle the bus, circle the trucks. Help them as needed.

Ask the child to circle the traffic and then to circle the buildings.
